Control Title: Application and Interface Security Policy and Procedures
Control Specification:
Establish, document, approve, communicate, apply, evaluate and 
maintain policies and procedures for application security to 
provide guidance to the appropriate planning, delivery and 
support of the organization's application security capabilities. 
Review and update the policies and procedures at least annually 
or after significant system changes occur that could impact risk exposure.

Establish, document and maintain baseline requirements for 
securing different applications.

Define and implement technical and operational metrics in alignment
with business objectives, security requirements, and compliance obligations.

Define and implement a software development lifecycle (SDLC) process for application design, development,
deployment, and operation in accordance with security requirements defined by
the organization.

Implement a testing strategy, including criteria for acceptance of
new information systems, upgrades and new versions, which provides application
security assurance and maintains compliance while enabling organizational speed
of delivery goals. Automate when applicable and possible.

Establish and implement strategies and capabilities for secure, standardized,
and compliant application deployment. Automate where possible.

Define and implement a process to remediate application security
vulnerabilities, automating remediation when possible.

Validate input data for accuracy, completeness, and consistency before using it for training models. Identify and remove outliers that deviate significantly from expected patterns. Pay special attention to user input if allowed for training to prevent manipulation. Validate user input against adversarial patterns, failure patterns and unwanted behaviour, according to relevant first and third party standards.

Validate output format, syntax, semantic, safety checks, consistency and accuracy. Validate and sanitize output against patterns of adversarial attacks, in accordance with established guardrails and known insecure output patterns such as those covered in OWASP AI and LLM Top 10. This includes output directly from the model and output from the caching systems integrated with AI applications.

Implement technical security measures and processes to help protect APIs, including authorization flaws, API key management, regular security testing of APIs, and other unique threats to the API's supporting business software. Review and update these technical measures for any improvements at least annually.

Control Title: Code Review, Version Control, and Static Code Analysis
Control Specification: Implement model development practices, such as version control, code review & static code analysis, aligning with the SDLC process established in AIS-04.

Restrict access in agent-based solutions to only the tools and plugins strictly necessary for the activity or use case at hand, ensuring resource segregation and adherence to the principle of least privilege.

Perform preliminary validation of input parameters provided to tools and plugins used by agents before execution, including type checks, format checks, range checks, and sanitization of input against malicious sequences (e.g., SQL Injection Strings).

Implement sandboxing techniques to execute tools and 
plugins in isolated environments to prevent unintended 
interactions with critical systems or data and limit the 
possibility of lateral movement.

Implement security measures to protect cache systems in 
LLMs, including encryption of data, application of strict 
access controls, and mechanisms to avoid the retention of 
sensitive information in fast memory, mitigating the risk of 
unauthorized access or data poisoning.

Implement mechanisms enabling the model to clearly distinguish user-provided input instructions from data and system instructions (e.g., system prompts) using input formatting techniques (e.g., border strings, data marking) and standard templates to limit ambiguity or incorrect prioritization of instructions.
